text.p: The following Australian economic indicators and events are scheduled for next week.
DAY TIME Indicator Period Forecast Previous
Mon 0130 Housing Finance Mar +1.0 pct -6.9 pct
Mon 0130 Manufact output prices Mar n/f +0.2 pct
Wed 0430 Westpac Consumer Sent May n/f -0.7 pct
Wed 0830 Treasurer Costello at AFR post-budget dinner
Thu 0130 Manufact input prices Mar n/f -0.5 pct
Thu 0130 Export Price index Mar n/f +1.4 pct
Thu 0130 Import Price index Mar n/f +0.5 pct
Thu 0200 RBA Governor Macfarlane speaks in Melbourne
Wed 0430 Westpac leading index Mar +0.6 pct
Thu 0130 Wages data - final Feb qtr prelim +1.3 pct
Thu 0130 Comapny profits Q1 +8.6 pct Thu 0230 Treasury Sec Evans at ABE post-budget briefing

QUESTION OF THE WEEK - Ahead of the 1997/98 (July-June) budget on Tuesday, economists were asked for their forecasts of some of the budget's economic parameters. Forecasts were sought for GDP(A) growth and employment growth in year-average terms, and the underlying inflation rate for the four quarters to June 1998.

Both GDP and employment growth are expected to be stronger than the government's latest forecasts which were contained in the mid year review released in January. Then GDP(A) was seen at 3.5 percent and employment growth was expected to be 2.0 percent in 1997/98, although those forecasts are expected to be revised up in the Budget.

But while the economy is expected to be stronger, and the labour market to show some improvement, underlying inflation should remain comfortably within the Reserve Bank's two to three percent target range.

HOUSING FINANCE - Most forecasts are around a flat result, in line with Australian Bankers Association data. The differences tend to come from whether or not banks are expected to continue their recent underperformance of other lenders. Pulling the median up are some expectations of a reversal of March's 6.9 percent fall, in line with forecasts of a housing upswing and generally stronger economy.
